A. Hicks Lawrence answers:
A. HICKS LAWRENCE, JR., earned his B.E. degree from Yale in June 1940 and joined Du Pont
in the following month as an analytical chemist.
He progressed steadily at various plants, from
line foreman to shift supervisor to senior supervisor. In 1949 he applied his technical training to
mansales work. Today Mr. Lawrence is a sales
ager in the "Kinetic" Division of Du Pont's
Organic Chemicals Department.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DEC. 9,

NEWS-LETTER

Old Evergreen House Contains
Rare Books, Coins, Picassos
.

By RON ENGEL
Assistant Features Editor

The imposing, classically moteled mansion set amid quiet evergreens at 4545 North Charles
Street, between the campuses of
Loyola and Notre Dame Colleges,
is the former home of Mr. an
Mrs. John Work Garrett, and now
the little-known but singularly
valuable property of the Johns
Hopkins University.
Within its pale yellow, ornate,
and yet gracious facade is the
Garrett 35,000 volume, "Four
Generation Library", one
of
America's most nc table collections

dent and gave the use of the railroad to the Union Army during
the Civil War. His son, Thomas
Harrison Garret' initiated the
collection of books, prints, and
coins and interested his son, John
Work Garrett, an invalid in childhood, in natural history, especially.
ornithology.
John W. Garrett, after graduation from Princeton, entered the
Diplomatic Service, and in 1929
became the United States Ambassador to Italy. These two aspects
of his life—his early enthusiasm
for outdoor life and books inherited from his father, and his

Ken McGraw Earns Place
As ACS All American

Final Cuts Made
Frosh Five Looks

Ken McGraw, junior tackle on
the Hopkins football team, has
been named to the American
Chemical Society's All-American
football team for his play with
the Blue Jays this year.
The team is picked by the editors of Chemical Engineering News
and has ten teams represented.
West Virginia and Princeton each
placed two men on the team. Five
backs are listed because the editors could not decide on a top four.
All the members of the team are
chemistry'majors.
McGraw is a junior in chemistry
with a B plus average. He has averaged 58 minutes a game in all
but two outings for the Jays. Hop-

(Continued from Page 7)
height and speed, when combined
with his small guards.
Dick Weinstein, 6'6" freshman
president, is currently handling
the center post, after displaying
good form in drills. He is being
backed up by Erv Sekulow, a
former star in the Baltimore high
school ranks.
At the forward position, five
tall cagers are battling for the
starting roles. According to Scott,
Chuck Loughran, Charley McLeod,
Howard Leibowitz, Pete Greenberg, and Joel Miller seem capable of capturing these two positions. Also in the battle for the
starting forward positions are
three smaller boys, Morris Jones,
Al Seivold, and Dave Shigekawa.
Scoring Punch Shown
In the back court for the Jays,
Pat Riley, Bob Williams, Billy
Morrill, an Ed Bernstein have
displayed court knowhow, and
scoring
punch. According
to
Scott, Riley has shown himself
to be an excellent floor leader and,
probably, will be one of the starting guards. Backing up this group
are Mickey Webster, Mal Levine,
and Bruce Duffany. Scott stated
that he expects these boys to
give the top four considerable
pressure. Scott considers his
guards to be a good nucleus of
potential scorers, and one of his
team's brightest spots.

Members three weeks ago.

Swartz stated that he was favorably impressed with the chapter's
organization and the facilities
on the
Hopkins Campus. Beta
Circle accepted the offer at last

Frosh Schedules Conflict Panel To Discuss

mission and Officer proceedings
in lieu of the meetings.
Concerning Class Day, the frosh
president stated that he would
like to "congratulate the frosh on
Class Day. They did a wonderful
job and showed fine spirit. If
that spirit remains, the Class of
'59 will be one tremendous class."
Weinstein announced that this
year's 16th Annual Christmas Assembly must be decorated by the
frosh. Anyone interested is asked
to drop a note in Box 2115 as
soon as possible. Definite planning will begin on Saturday.
Freshmen will also be needed
along with sophomores to decorate for the Freshmen-Sophomore
Prom to be held in February.
Roger McKinley, freshman
Commission member, announced
that a symbol, motto, or emblem
for the Class of '59 is being sought
by the Commission and class officers. A free 1956 Hullaballoo will
be given to the winner of the contest, which will end December 21,
and will be judged by a three-man
committee chosen from the freshGirls from Villa Jolie and Tow- men by McKinley, chairman of
son State Teachers College will be the campaign, to whom all entries
present at tonight's mixer from 8 should be submitted, at Box 2190.
to 12 in the recreation room of the
Alumni Memorial Residences, according to Herb Kahler, chairman
of the Dormitory Social Commit
tee.
The mixer is open to all residents of the dormitory, and a fee
of 25 cents will be charged to cover
the costs of refreshments.
Kahler stated, "Probably the attendance will be limited to 150
boys—first come, first served."
This stipulation is necessitated by
the small size of the room.
Another social event taking
place in the vicinity is the Hampton House Christmas Dance, sponsored by the Johns Hopkins Nursing Home. This event will take
place from 9 until one tomorrow
night in the Hampton House. Admission is $2.

Meetings of the freshman class
are an impossibility, due to the
awangement of the freshman
schedules, according to Class
President Dick • Weinstein.
"We've checked and double
checked," stated Weinstein, "and
we just can't have meetings. The
only hour free for meetings is the
hour between 12 noon and 1 p.m.",
this hour is impractical for a class
Meeting in Weinsteins opinion.
Weinstein consulted Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Director. of Student
Activities, concerning the matter
and arrived at a possible solution which would mean the eliminating of the Orientation Meeting
"Bull Sessions," but the approval
of all advisors is needed for this
to go into effect.
Weinstein announced that the
group will begin to print and distribute bulletins concerning Corn-

discussion at the Tuesday Coffee
Hour in Levering Great Hall.

countries, including representatives of Palestine, South American
and European countries.
Paul Niebank, Y Cabinet member, stated that "In these periods,
the Y feels that the students have
a chance to cross departmental
lines and broaden their field of
vision." These meetings are cosponsored by the Y, the Veterans

Association, and the Cosmopolitan Club.

ager in the "Kinetic" Division of Du Pont's
Organic Chemicals Department.

Ken McGraw Earns Place
As ACS All American

Final Cuts Made
Frosh Five Looks
To MC Contest

Ken McGraw, junior tackle on
the Hopkins football team, has
been named to the American
Chemical Society's All-American
football team for his play with
the Blue Jays this year.
The team is picked by the editors of Chemical Engineering News
and has ten teams represented.
West Virginia and Princeton each
placed two men on the team. Five
backs are listed because the editors could not decide on a top four.
All the members of the team are
chemistry'majors.
McGraw is a junior in chemistry
with a B plus average. He has averaged 58 minutes a game in all
but two outings for the Jays. Hop-

(Continued from Page 7)
height and speed, when combined
with his small guards.
Dick Weinstein, 6'6" freshman
president, is currently handling
the center post, after displaying
good form in drills. He is being
backed up by Erv Sekulow, a
former star in the Baltimore high
school ranks.
At the forward position, five
tall cagers are battling for the
starting roles. According to Scott,
Chuck Loughran, Charley McLeod,
Howard Leibowitz, Pete Greenberg, and Joel Miller seem capable of capturing these two positions. Also in the battle for the
starting forward positions are
three smaller boys, Morris Jones,
Al Seivold, and Dave Shigekawa.
Scoring Punch Shown
In the back court for the Jays,
Pat Riley, Bob Williams, Billy
Morrill, an Ed Bernstein have
displayed court knowhow, and
scoring
punch. According
to
Scott, Riley has shown himself
to be an excellent floor leader and,
probably, will be one of the starting guards. Backing up this group
are Mickey Webster, Mal Levine,
and Bruce Duffany. Scott stated
that he expects these boys to
give the top four considerable
pressure. Scott considers his
guards to be a good nucleus of
potential scorers, and one of his
team's brightest spots.

ODK Circle To Host
g, Next Provincial Conclave
Beta Circle, the Johns Hopkins
Chapter of Omicron Delta Kappa,
the national leadership fraternity,
has accepted an offer to be host
for an ODE Provincial Convention
to be held in late
February or early
March, stated President Herbert
Belgrad.
The invitation was extended to
Beta Circle by Dr. Donald E.
Swartz, deputy chief of the Northeast Province of ODE. According
to Belgrad,
the offer came as a
result of a recent visit to the Hopkins chapter by Dr. Swartz. He
aided Belgrad and Jim Pessin, secretary, with the initiation of new
Members three weeks ago.
In a letter to the local ODE,
Swartz stated that he was favorably impressed with the chapter's
organization and the facilities
on the
Hopkins Campus. Beta
Circle accepted the offer at last
Week's meeting, and Steve Carney

Frosh Schedules Conflict Panel To Discuss
Xmas, Hanukkah
With Proposed Meetings
mission and Officer proceedings
in lieu of the meetings.
Concerning Class Day, the frosh
president stated that he would
like to "congratulate the frosh on
Class Day. They did a wonderful
job and showed fine spirit. If
that spirit remains, the Class of
'59 will be one tremendous class."
Weinstein announced that this
year's 16th Annual Christmas Assembly must be decorated by the
frosh. Anyone interested is asked
to drop a note in Box 2115 as
soon as possible. Definite planning will begin on Saturday.
Freshmen will also be needed
along with sophomores to decorate for the Freshmen-Sophomore
Prom to be held in February.
Roger McKinley, freshman
Commission member, announced
that a symbol, motto, or emblem
for the Class of '59 is being sought
by the Commission and class officers. A free 1956 Hullaballoo will
be given to the winner of the contest, which will end December 21,
and will be judged by a three-man
committee chosen from the freshGirls from Villa Jolie and Tow- men by McKinley, chairman of
son State Teachers College will be the campaign, to whom all entries
present at tonight's mixer from 8 should be submitted, at Box 2190.
to 12 in the recreation room of the
Alumni Memorial Residences, according to Herb Kahler, chairman
of the Dormitory Social Commit
tee.
The mixer is open to all residents of the dormitory, and a fee
of 25 cents will be charged to cover
the costs of refreshments.
Kahler stated, "Probably the attendance will be limited to 150
boys—first come, first served."
This stipulation is necessitated by
the small size of the room.
Another social event taking
place in the vicinity is the Hampton House Christmas Dance, sponsored by the Johns Hopkins Nursing Home. This event will take
place from 9 until one tomorrow
night in the Hampton House. Admission is $2.

Meetings of the freshman class
are an impossibility, due to the
awangement of the freshman
schedules, according to Class
President Dick • Weinstein.
"We've checked and double
checked," stated Weinstein, "and
we just can't have meetings. The
only hour free for meetings is the
hour between 12 noon and 1 p.m.",
this hour is impractical for a class
Meeting in Weinsteins opinion.
Weinstein consulted Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Director. of Student
Activities, concerning the matter
and arrived at a possible solution which would mean the eliminating of the Orientation Meeting
"Bull Sessions," but the approval
of all advisors is needed for this
to go into effect.
Weinstein announced that the
group will begin to print and distribute bulletins concerning Corn-

"Christmas and Chanukah in
the West" will be topics in a panel
discussion at the Tuesday Coffee
Hour in Levering Great Hall.
On the panel will be six or seven
stud7nts from different Western
countries, including representatives of Palestine, South American
and European countries.
Paul Niebank, Y Cabinet member, stated that "In these periods,
the Y feels that the students have
a chance to cross departmental
lines and broaden their field of
vision." These meetings are cosponsored by the Y, the Veterans
Students Club, t h e Graduate
Association, and the Cosmopolitan Club.
